questions.text:
Two weeks after undergoing an emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for unstable angina pectoris, a 61-year-old man has decreased urinary output and malaise. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin and naproxen. He was also started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol after the coronary intervention. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin count
14 g/dL


Leukocyte count
16,400/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
56%


 Eosinophils

11%


 Lymphocytes
31%


 Monocytes
2%


Platelet count
260,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
68 mm/h


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


 Creatinine

4.2 mg/dL


Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In contrast-induced nephropathy, creatinine is highest after 3–5 days and usually normalizes to the patient's baseline within 1 week. Nephrotoxic drugs such NSAIDs increase the risk of kidney damage following contrast administration. Although this patient takes naproxen regularly, the onset of symptoms, eosinophilia, and renal biopsy results are not consistent with this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with renal papillary necrosis typically present with hematuria, flank pain, fever, and colicky pain. Urinalysis may show pyuria/WBC casts without eosinophils. However, kidney biopsy of a patient with renal papillary necrosis would reveal coagulative necrosis of the renal medulla and papillae rather than spindle-shaped vacuoles. Moreover, skin findings are usually not seen in renal papillary necrosis, which makes this diagnosis less likely in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to medications such as NSAIDs or penicillins. Patients present with fever, rash, eosinophilia, eosinophiluria, and sterile pyuria. Although this patient's symptoms overlap with those of AIN, the biopsy results rule out this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Analgesic nephropathy is the most common cause of chronic interstitial nephritis. It is caused by inhibition of prostacyclins by NSAIDs, which in turn causes vasoconstriction of the medullary blood vessels, leading to papillary ischemia and necrosis. It manifests with painless hematuria, pyuria, fatigue, and nausea. This patient presents with acute symptoms after cardiac catheterization, which should raise suspicion for another condition. Furthermore, analgesic nephropathy does not account for this patient's skin findings.

E) CORRECT:

Cholesterol embolization syndrome typically affects older individuals with underlying atherosclerosis, particularly after invasive vascular procedures (e.g., cardiac catheterization, arteriography). Cholesterol crystals dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques and enter the bloodstream, blocking small to medium-sized arteries in various organs. Patients typically present with nonspecific systemic inflammatory features (e.g., fever, elevated ESR, eosinophilia) and various types of end-organ damage, depending on the embolism location (e.g., acute renal failure, peripheral skin manifestations such as livedo reticularis). The diagnosis is mostly clinical and may be supported by laboratory and imaging studies. In patients with renal manifestations, urine studies may show proteinuria, hematuria, and/or eosinophiluria. A kidney biopsy showing spindle-shaped vacuoles (intravascular cholesterol deposits) is the only definitive test to confirm the diagnosis, but it is not routinely performed. Treatment primarily focuses on prevention of recurrence and includes management of ASCVD and removal of the embolic source, e.g., in patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of renal tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Spindle-shaped, white spaces (yellow overlay) can be seen in an arterial vessel (dashed outline). These spaces (cholesterol clefts) are formed when the fat molecules in cholesterol emboli dissolve during sample processing.

F) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas with eosinophilia. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, and kidneys. It classically manifests with severe allergic asthma attacks and allergic rhinitis, neither of which is present in this patient.
questions.hint: This condition can also manifest as blue toe syndrome and can be seen in patients undergoing endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing emergency cardiac catheterization for myocardial infarction, a 68-year-old woman develops pain in her toes. During the intervention, she was found to have an occluded left anterior descending artery and three stents were placed. She has hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and coronary artery disease. Prior to admission, her medications were metoprolol, enalapril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 115/78 mm Hg. Examination shows discoloration of the toes of both feet. A photograph of the right foot is shown. The lesions are cool and tender to palpation. The rest of the skin on the feet is warm; femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In cholesterol embolization syndrome, ruptured plaque material can seed anywhere in the peripheral arteries, including the renal arteries, which subsequently impairs kidney function, manifesting as acute or subacute kidney injury. There is no specific treatment for cholesterol embolization syndrome. The mainstay of management is the prevention of recurrence, e.g., by optimizing the management of atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases. Removal of the embolic source can be considered in consultation with a specialist. Options include surgical treatment (e.g., vascular bypass surgery, endarterectomy) and interventional treatment (e.g., angioplasty, endovascular stent grafting). Even with optimal treatment, the prognosis of cholesterol embolization syndrome remains poor.

B) INCORRECT:

Lipodermatosclerosis is a classic finding in chronic venous disease (CVD), which is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It manifests with painfully indurated skin and, in advanced stages, atrophic skin plaques (atrophie blanche). It would not manifest with bluish-purple discolorations of the skin. While CVD can be painful, this patient lacks other classical features of CVD, such as edema and/or pain that worsens on standing and is relieved when the legs are raised.
Image Description:

Lower legs of a male patient with chronic venous disease

Areas of shiny purpura and yellowish-brown skin pigmentation are visible on the distal lower legs and on the dorsum of the feet. There are white, coin-sized atrophic plaques (atrophie blanche) medially above the level of the ankle.

C) INCORRECT:

In early stages, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) can manifest with painful, bluish-purple discoloration of digits. However, the absence of a possible trigger for coagulopathy (such as infection or sepsis), as well as the appearance of symptoms following cardiac catheterization, makes another condition more likely in this patient. The patient also lacks other cutaneous findings indicating DIC, such as petechiae and purpura.

D) INCORRECT:

Lower extremity compartment syndrome is caused by acute, sharp increases in tissue pressures within the muscular compartment of the lower legs, resulting in acute limb ischemia. It is classically trauma-induced but can also be caused by shock and coagulopathy. Patients often present with signs of acute limb ischemia (the 6 Ps). Depending on the amount of internal tissue pressure, peripheral pulses are often still palpable (as in this patient). However, the combination of the warm foot, the localization of the pain (in the toes), and the amount of pain (not out of proportion to the extent of the injury) is inconsistent with compartment syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Basophilia is not a typical finding in cholesterol embolization syndrome. Rather, increased eosinophils are commonly detected (in up to 80% of cases). Eosinophilia is assumed to be the result of a cytokine-mediated disorder, but the exact mechanism is not yet fully understood.

F) INCORRECT:

Popliteal aneurysms are the result of chronic lower limb ischemia (peripheral artery disease, or PAD). Popliteal aneurysms are high-risk locations for obstruction of blood flow and subsequent thrombi formation, which can then embolize distally. Coronary heart disease, which this patient has, and PAD do share some of the same risk factors. However, there is no evidence for PAD in this patient's history (e.g., intermittent claudication). Furthermore, signs of embolization are seen in both feet, which suggests that the source of embolization is above the aortic bifurcation.

G) INCORRECT:

Volkmann contracture is a complication of upper extremity compartment syndrome that occurs after permanent ischemia of the flexor muscles and the hand and fingers. It is often caused by applying plaster casts that are too tight and ultimately results in a claw-like deformity of the fingers, hand, and wrist. This patient does not have signs of upper limb ischemia such as pain, pallor, or paresthesias. Another complication of cholesterol embolization syndrome is more likely.

H) INCORRECT:

Migratory thrombophlebitis is an obliterating inflammation of the superficial veins that can be caused by vasculitis, contaminated IV catheters, or occult malignancy. It typically manifests as a tender, indurated erythema along the course of a vein. Occasionally, a cord-like structure (thrombosed vein) can be palpated. Cholesterol embolization usually involves peripheral arterial embolization and does not affect the superficial veins. Another complication is more likely.
questions.hint: The photograph shows purplish discoloration of the toes and livedo reticularis of the back of the foot. Cardiac catheterization most likely caused cholesterol emboli to be released, which then lodged in both feet, leading to blue toe syndrome.

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing an emergency cardiac catheterization for unstable angina pectoris, a 65-year-old man has decreased urinary output. He takes naproxen for osteoarthritis and was started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol after the coronary intervention. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 128/88 mm Hg. Examination shows mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet and ischemic changes on the right big toe. His leukocyte count is 16,500/mm3 with 56% segmented neutrophils, 12% eosinophils, 30% lymphocytes, and 2% monocytes. His serum creatinine concentration is 4.5 mg/dL. A photomicrograph of a kidney biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to medications such as NSAIDs or penicillins. Unlike here, patients present with fever, rash, eosinophilia, eosinophiluria, and sterile pyuria. Although this patient's symptoms overlap with those of AIN, the presence of blue toe syndrome and the biopsy results rule out this diagnosis.

B) CORRECT:

Cholesterol embolization syndrome is a condition in which cholesterol crystals dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques and enter the bloodstream, blocking small to medium-sized arteries in various organs. Incidence is highest in older individuals with underlying atherosclerosis, particularly after invasive vascular procedures (e.g., percutaneous coronary intervention). Patients typically present with nonspecific features of systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, eosinophilia) and various types of end-organ damage, depending on the embolism location (e.g., acute renal failure, peripheral skin manifestations such as livedo reticularis). The diagnosis is mostly clinical and may be supported by laboratory and imaging studies. In patients with renal manifestations, urine studies may show proteinuria, hematuria, and/or eosinophiluria. A kidney biopsy showing spindle-shaped vacuoles (intravascular cholesterol deposits) is the only definitive test to confirm the diagnosis, but it is not routinely performed due to the risk of side effects and the availability of less invasive diagnostic procedures.

C) INCORRECT:

In contrast-induced nephropathy, creatinine is highest after 3–5 days and usually normalizes to the patient's baseline within 1 week. Nephrotoxic drugs, such as NSAIDs, increase the risk of kidney damage following contrast administration. Although this patient takes naproxen regularly, neither the onset of symptoms nor the renal biopsy results is consistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Kidney biopsy of a patient with renal papillary necrosis would reveal coagulative necrosis of the renal medulla and papillae rather than spindle-shaped vacuoles. Unlike here, patients with renal papillary necrosis typically present with hematuria, flank pain, fever, and colicky pain. Urinalysis may show pyuria/WBC casts without eosinophils. In addition, skin findings and blue toe syndrome are not expected in renal papillary necrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas with eosinophilia. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, and kidneys. It classically presents with severe allergic asthma attacks and allergic rhinitis, neither of which is present in this patient. In addition, a biopsy of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis would show eosinophilic tissue with granulomatous reactions.
questions.hint: This condition can also be seen in patients undergoing endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.

questions.text: Two days after admission to the hospital for elective coronary angiography and stent placement in the left anterior descending artery for treatment of stable angina pectoris, a 63-year-old man develops a rash on his left foot. Prior to the angiography, he received a heparin bolus. He has hypertension and steatohepatitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and drinks one to two beers weekly. His medications include simvastatin, aspirin, and atenolol. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Skin examination shows a tender, reticulated blue-red discoloration of the left calf without swelling and several nonblanching reddish maculae on the lateral foot and the toes. Pedal pulses are 1+ bilaterally. Sensation to touch and temperature is normal over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's rash?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower limb can lead to tenderness and discoloration of the skin in a patient with multiple risk factors for DVT (age > 60 years, smoking, immobilization). However, DVT typically manifests with swelling, warmth, and erythema of the affected limb, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, distal pulses are typically normal in DVT.

B) INCORRECT:

Cryoglobulinemia can lead to cryoglobulinemic vasculitis and manifest with skin discoloration. However, most cases of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis are associated with hepatitis C infection and characterized by fatigue, arthralgias, vasomotor symptoms (e.g., Raynaud phenomenon), and polyneuropathy, none of which are seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Atheroembolism is the embolization of multiple cholesterol crystals and atherosclerotic debris, usually to small and medium-sized arteries, following endovascular interventions (e.g., coronary angiography with stent placement), after the initiation of anticoagulant therapy, or spontaneously. Atheroembolism most commonly occurs in older individuals with multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., hypertension, coronary artery disease, steatohepatitis, smoking). The embolization of microscopic cholesterol crystals into small arterioles affects many organs, and affected individuals can present with skin changes (e.g., livedo reticularis, blue toe syndrome), gastrointestinal ischemia, pancreatitis, CNS symptoms (transient ischemic attack, stroke), or acute kidney injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT; formerly called type 2 HIT), a severe complication of heparin therapy that can cause skin necrosis due to arterial thrombosis, would explain this patient's lower extremity skin changes. However, HIT usually develops 5 to 10 days after continuous heparin therapy, whereas this patient received a single heparin bolus 2 days ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lower limb ischemia can manifest with sudden onset of unilateral tenderness and skin discoloration of the lower extremity. Nevertheless, other features of acute limb ischemia (6 Ps), such as absent peripheral pulses (pulselessness), decreased lower limb sensation (paresthesia), and paralysis, are absent here.
questions.hint: This condition also frequently leads to acute kidney injury.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease and a 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking presents with new skin lesions on her lower extremities (figure).
One week before presentation, she was hospitalized for unstable angina and underwent cardiac catheterization with placement of two drug-eluting stents in her left anterior descending and circumflex arteries. She was discharged on lisinopril 20 mg daily, metoprolol 50 mg twice daily, aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, atorvastatin 20 mg daily, and omeprazole 40 mg daily.
The right groin shows a clean puncture site without ecchymosis or palpable hematoma. Vital signs and physical examination are otherwise unremarkable.
Laboratory testing is unremarkable with the exception of a serum creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL (compared with a baseline value of 1.6 and a reference range of 0.6–1.1), eosinophils 12% (0–8) and blood urea nitrogen 30 mg/dL (10–20). Her hemoglobin level is 10.8 g/dL (12–16), her hematocrit is 33.1% (36–46), and her platelet count is 185,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000).
Urinalysis shows 5 to 10 white cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2); urine Gram stain is negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The finding of white blood cells in the urine and peripheral eosinophilia are consistent with interstitial nephritis, but these signs are nonspecific. In addition, when present, the rash seen in drug-induced interstitial nephritis is characterized by erythematous macules and papules or urticaria (similar to any cutaneous drug reaction) and is not accompanied by livedo reticularis.

B) INCORRECT:

The skin findings of immunoglobulin A (IgA) vasculitis (formerly referred to as Henoch-Schönlein purpura) are typically clusters of ecchymoses, petechiae, and palpable lesions that are distinct from livedo reticularis. In this case, the temporal relationship of the procedure to the decline in renal function and the skin changes makes IgA vasculitis unlikely. IgA vasculitis is a systemic illness and would be accompanied by other systemic manifestations.

C) INCORRECT:

Case reports have suggested that the antiplatelet agent clopidogrel can cause thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), but clear evidence is lacking. This patient's platelet count is in the normal range, which makes a diagnosis of TTP unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Atheroembolic kidney disease occurs when atheromatous material is dislodged from the arteries and travels distally to occlude arteries and arterioles. This can occur following any vascular intervention, including cardiac catheterization. Risk factors include advanced age, hypertension, coronary or peripheral vascular disease, and smoking. Livedo reticularis (typically seen on both legs, as in this case) and blue toe syndrome are the most common clinical signs of cholesterol crystal embolism, occurring in 35% of cases. Unlike the acute presentation of contrast nephropathy, cholesterol embolization typically results in a subacute presentation. In the first week after cholesterol embolization, some patients may have peripheral eosinophilia, eosinophiluria, and hypocomplementemia.

Key learning point: Acute kidney injury accompanied by livedo reticularis after cardiac catheterization is indicative of cholesterol crystal embolization.

E) INCORRECT:

Contrast nephropathy is associated with an acute elevation in serum creatinine within 48 hours after contrast exposure but is not accompanied by livedo reticularis.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man presents with new-onset flank pain, reduced urine output, and small purple lesions on his toes. He has a history of stable coronary artery disease and underwent cardiac catheterization two weeks ago. Laboratory analysis shows a rising serum creatinine from 1.3 mg/dL to 3.0 mg/dL. Urine examination reveals RBCs, white blood cells, and eosinophils.
Which of the following conditions is the most likely explanation of this patient’s acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Cholesterol microembolization syndrome occurs when atheromatous plaques release cholesterol crystals into the circulation, often after vascular procedures like cardiac catheterization. These emboli lodge in small arteries, causing ischemia and inflammation, leading to acute kidney injury. The patient's symptoms, including flank pain, reduced urine output, and purple toe lesions, indicate embolic showers affecting multiple vascular beds. Urinalysis showing red blood cells, white blood cells, and eosinophils supports vascular inflammation. The timing of symptoms, two weeks post-catheterization, aligns with cholesterol emboli dislodgment and occlusion of small vessels.

Key learning point: Eosinophiluria is suggestive of cholesterol emboli as a cause of acute renal failure, especially following procedures like cardiac catheterization.

B) INCORRECT:

Thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) involves microvascular thrombosis, causing acute kidney injury, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. This patient lacks evidence of hemolysis, low platelet count, or neurological symptoms typical of TMA. Urinary eosinophils and purple toe lesions post-catheterization suggest embolic phenomena, not the thrombotic changes seen in TMA.

C) INCORRECT:

Contrast-induced nephropathy typically occurs within 24–72 hours post-contrast exposure, with a rapid, transient creatinine rise and no systemic findings. This patient's renal dysfunction developed two weeks post-catheterization, inconsistent with contrast nephropathy. Flank pain, purple toe lesions, and urinary eosinophils suggest an inflammatory process with multisystem involvement, indicating an embolic etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is a hypersensitivity reaction to medications, presenting with fever, rash, and eosinophilia. While urinary eosinophils might suggest AIN, the patient's recent catheterization and purple toe lesions indicate an embolic process. AIN rarely presents with vascular manifestations like skin changes, and the timing of creatinine rise post-catheterization suggests an embolic rather than hypersensitivity cause.

questions.text:
Two weeks after you performed an emergency cardiac catheterization with stenting for unstable angina, a 61-year-old man presents with decreased urinary output and malaise. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoarthritis of the hips. Before admission, his medications included insulin and naproxen. Following the coronary intervention, he was started on aspirin, clopidogrel, and metoprolol. His temperature is 38°C, pulse is 93/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. On examination, there is mottled, reticulated purplish discoloration of the feet. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
140 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
16.4 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Neutrophils, absolute, blood
9.2 × 109/L (2.0–7.5)


Eosinophils, blood
1.8 × 109/L (0–0.5)


Lymphocytes, blood
5.1 × 109/L (0.8–3.5)


Monocytes, blood
0.3 × 109/L (0.1–1.0)


Platelet count, blood
260 × 109/L (130–380)


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), blood
68 mm/h (0–10)


Urea, blood
8.9 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood

372 μmol/L (49–93)


Renal biopsy shows intravascular spindle-shaped vacuoles. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas with eosinophilia. It commonly involves the lungs, skin, and kidneys. It classically manifests with severe allergic asthma attacks and allergic rhinitis, neither of which is present in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Cholesterol embolization syndrome typically affects older individuals with underlying atherosclerosis, particularly after invasive vascular procedures (e.g., cardiac catheterization, arteriography). Cholesterol crystals dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques and enter the bloodstream, blocking small to medium-sized arteries in various organs. Patients typically present with nonspecific systemic inflammatory features (e.g., fever, elevated ESR, eosinophilia) and various types of end-organ damage, depending on the embolism location (e.g., acute renal failure, peripheral skin manifestations such as livedo reticularis). The diagnosis is mostly clinical and may be supported by laboratory and imaging studies. In patients with renal manifestations, urine studies may show proteinuria, hematuria, and/or eosinophiluria. A kidney biopsy showing spindle-shaped vacuoles (intravascular cholesterol deposits) is the only definitive test to confirm the diagnosis, but it is not routinely performed. Treatment primarily focuses on prevention of recurrence and includes management of ASCVD and removal of the embolic source, e.g., in patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Key learning point: Cholesterol embolization syndrome occurs after vascular procedures when cholesterol crystals dislodge from atherosclerotic plaques, causing multisystem ischemia, livedo reticularis, eosinophilia, and acute kidney injury with characteristic spindle-shaped vacuoles on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of renal tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Spindle-shaped, white spaces (yellow overlay) can be seen in an arterial vessel (dashed outline). These spaces (cholesterol clefts) are formed when the fat molecules in cholesterol emboli dissolve during sample processing.

C) INCORRECT:

In contrast-induced nephropathy, creatinine is highest after 3–5 days and usually normalizes to the patient's baseline within 1 week. Nephrotoxic drugs such NSAIDs increase the risk of kidney damage following contrast administration. Although this patient takes naproxen regularly, the onset of symptoms, eosinophilia, and renal biopsy results are not consistent with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) is caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to medications such as NSAIDs or penicillins. Patients present with fever, rash, eosinophilia, eosinophiluria, and sterile pyuria. Although this patient's symptoms overlap with those of AIN, the biopsy results rule out this diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with renal papillary necrosis typically present with hematuria, flank pain, fever, and colicky pain. Urinalysis may show pyuria/WBC casts without eosinophils. However, kidney biopsy of a patient with renal papillary necrosis would reveal coagulative necrosis of the renal medulla and papillae rather than spindle-shaped vacuoles. Moreover, skin findings are usually not seen in renal papillary necrosis, which makes this diagnosis less likely in this patient.
questions.hint: This condition can also manifest as blue toe syndrome and can be seen in patients undergoing endovascular abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.
